div.div: Student Support | Raising Awareness | Coronavirus | Skip to Content

h3.strong: ALL PUSD SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED TO STUDENTS FROM MONDAY, MARCH 16 UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

p.br: FOR THE VERY LATEST INFORMATION ON 2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) PLEASE VISIT THE SAN DIEGO COUNTY HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES AGENCY WEBSITE

hr.p:
Dear Team PUSD,
I hope you and your families are safe and healthy. We miss seeing our students during this time of physical distancing. I know that this has been difficult for many of us. I appreciate your patience and understanding of the tremendous effort it took to roll out our distance learning initiative to over 36,500 students. Many have asked or inquired whether the participation in distance learning is optional. The State Superintendent of Education has clearly stated distance learning is “absolutely necessary given the health challenges we are facing… school for the year is not done.” Just as attending school is not optional, distance learning is not optional. Distance learning has moved school out of the classroom and onto an online platform. To minimize the disruption in our students’ education, we expect our students to continue learning and building upon the knowledge and skills they’ve acquired throughout the school year. We need your help to ensure your child is ready to progress to the next grade level in the Fall.
Governor Gavin Newsom recently unveiled California’s Roadmap to Modify the Stay-at-Home Order, which describes six indicators that must be met before he will consider lifting the order. Based on the Governor’s Roadmap, the San Diego County Office of Education has created a long-term planning document for local K-12 districts. You can review the detailed document here. I realize some of the information is quite sobering and may be difficult to process, but I wanted to provide you with the information that district leaders across our county are using as a guide and reference as we make decisions that impact our schools and students.
According to the Governor and the CDC, schools will not return to normal (prepandemic) operations unless all of the following conditions have been met:
a. If the California stay-at-home order has been lifted
b. If the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in San Diego County has remained constant or declined for 28 consecutive days
c. If the directive to physically distance has been removed
d. If limits on group gatherings have been lifted
Based on the SDCOE’s planning document, if and when schools are permitted to re-open, the following modified operations will be required:
a. Proactive screening of students and staff for symptoms
b. Social distancing and face coverings in all settings
c. Limits on group gathering size (Loosening of restrictions is likely to be stepped down in phases - such as limiting the number of students on campus and in classrooms at one time)
While we have seen some promising signs of “flattening the curve,” the number of COVID-19 cases and deaths in San Diego County continue to rise. Our County’s stay at home order remains in effect. At this point, meeting the conditions for reopening our schools may not be likely prior to the end of the 2019-20 school year. The above guidelines are based on the current public health situation and current knowledge of the virus. Some of you have asked, why the District just doesn’t make the decision now to close schools through the end of the school year. As you have seen, circumstances during this pandemic change rapidly, and so there is no way to predict what will happen in the upcoming weeks or months. Like many of you, we are all trying to remain hopeful because our students, staff, and parents have expressed the strong desire to celebrate milestones and achievements together, if possible. I am tremendously impacted when I receive emails and messages from our graduating seniors, pleading for the opportunity to graduate with their classmates and not miss out on one of the most memorable moments in their lives. My job is to balance our students’ best interests with the health and safety of our community. That is why we have not yet made the final decision to close all schools through the end of the 2019-20 school year.
That said, superintendents across the county and the state have been advised to plan for alternatives to traditional graduation ceremonies and promotion assemblies. Thousands of parents, students, and staff participated in our recent survey regarding year-end ceremonies, and respondents overwhelmingly indicated a desire to postpone graduations and promotions until July or August, when it might be safe to gather in person. While this remains our priority and desire, it is also prudent to start considering alternative types of ceremonies in the event that it is still not safe to gather in July or August. We are forming committees of students, staff, and parents to develop viable options for us to consider as we plan for the 2019-20 graduation and promotion ceremonies.
Health experts have shared that a second wave of COVID-19 infections is expected, possibly coinciding with flu season in October or November. They anticipate this wave will not be as significant as the first but could result in site, district, regional, or countywide school closures for up to four weeks. This would require us to continue distance learning in the Fall. I assure you: PUSD remains committed to creating the highest quality educational experience possible for our students. PUSD will be prepared, should this be necessary.
Online learning and innovation has been accelerated for school districts across the country. We have turned the education model on a dime, and I know there are still ways we can improve. We have heard many success stories as well as challenges. Based on feedback from our students, parents, and staff, we are committed to continually refining and working hard to improve teaching and learning throughout PUSD. Our Technology and Innovation department continues to provide devices, internet access, professional development, and support for staff and students. Our administrators and teachers continue to refine their distance learning skills and capacity, to create robust and meaningful instruction for all students. You can view our distance learning plan here. This is the resource that guides our work.
Again, I realize all of this information can be overwhelming and presents huge challenges for staff as well as the families whom we serve. Please know that Team PUSD is committed to ensuring that we are prepared for whatever the future may hold for our District and students.
In partnership,
Marian Kim Phelps, Ed.D.
Superintendent

td.p: (No formal instruction, teachers connecting with students and families over Optional Learning Resources, technology distribution to teachers and students)
Teachers reach out to students to assess readiness and preparation to move to Distance Learning

hr.p: Starting Monday, March 23rd, PUSD will be consolidating meal service. From 11am to 1pm Monday through Friday, we will now be offering lunch and breakfast together. We hope that this will be more convenient for our families, allowing students to have one pick up time that includes both lunch and breakfast for the following day. This decision was based on feedback from our families as well as the data collected from the actual number of meals distributed this week.

These meals are free for anyone 18 years or younger in our community or for any PUSD Transition student 22 years or younger, but we ask that students needing meals be physically present for an accurate count. The meals will be available at the following 12 centralized school sites; please drive up or walk up to the site nearest you:

Westwood Elementary School (17449 Matinal Rd, San Diego, CA 92127)

div.hr: It is the goal of the Poway Unified School District that this website is accessible to all users. You can view our accessibility statement here. Please contact our Web Administrator for any accessibility issues at webmaster@powayusd.com.

p.span: The Poway Unified School District (PUSD) is an equal opportunity employer/program and is committed to an active Nondiscrimination Program. PUSD prohibits discrimination, harassment, intimidation, and bullying based on actual or perceived race, color, ancestry, national origin, nationality, immigration status, ethnicity, ethnic group identification, age, religion, marital or parental status, physical or mental ability, sex, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity, or gender expression or association with a person or a group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. For more information, please contact: Title IX/Equity Compliance Officer, James Jimenez, Associate Superintendent of Personnel Support Services, Poway Unified School District, 15250 Avenue of Science, San Diego, CA 92128, 1-858-521-2800, extension 2761, jjimenez@powayusd.com
